subject: FT writes that US is looking to exploit anger towards continued Chinese aggression in the South China Sea to rally rival claimants against Beijing
RBNZ buys NZD 450mln of government bonds in QE operations
RBA adds AUD 1.83bln to banking system through repos vs. Prev. AUD 520mln
PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIA AND SOUTH KOREA STOCK NEWS: Westpac H1 net fell 62% and Co. defers decision on dividends, North Korea and South Korea exchange gunfire at the border, Japan closed for holiday
content:
AUSTRALIA

Afterpay Touch (APT AT) - Tencent acquires around 13.4mln shares in the Co. (Newswires)

Crown Resorts (CWN AT) - Co. states normalized net was around AUD 210mln and normalized EBITDA was about AUD 500mln for 1st July 2019 - 23rd March 2020 period. (Newswires)

Decmil Group (DCG AT) - Co. is thought to have 3 strong offers for its Homeland Gladstone Accommodation Village. (Newswires)

Flight Centre (FLT AT) - Co. reported April Total Travel Value was 5%-10% of normal levels, while it announced to scrap cancellation fees after threat of legal action from ACCC. (Newswires)

Insurance Australia Group (IAG AT) - Co. affirms FY20 market guidance and said there is limited scope to pay a final dividend. (Newswires)

Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG AT) - Co. suspended from official quotation after having failed to lodge relevant periodic report by due date. (Newswires)

Tower Limited (TWR AT) - Co. appoints Blair Turnbull as CEO effective August 1st. (Newswires)

Treasury Wine Estates (TWE AT) - Co. acknowledged class action filed by Maurice Blackburn on behalf of shareholders who purchased shares between June 30th 2018 to January 28th 2020. (Newswires)

Virgin Australia (VAH AT) - Oaktree Capital is thought to be partnering with Etihad to bid for Virgin. (Newswires)

Virtus Health (VRT AT) - Co. is speculated to announce a capital raising. (Newswires)

Westpac (WBC AT) - Co. H1 net profit attributable fell 62% Y/Y to AUD 1.19bln, cash earnings AUD 993mln vs. Prev. AUD 3.30bln Y/Y, defers decision on dividends. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Asiana Airlines (020560 KS) - HDC Holdings  postponed plans to acquire the Co. (Newswires)

Hyundai Motor (005380 KS) - Co, April US vehicle sales fell 39% Y/Y to 34.0k units. (Newswires)

Kangwon Land (035250 KS) - Co. extended casino suspension by a week to May 11th. (Newswires)

Other News - South Korea decided to loosen social distancing restrictions as virus levels continue to remain low. (Newswires)

Geopolitics - North Korean leader Kim visited a factory in his first public appearance in 20 days and which follows conflicting reports in which some suggested he may have died or was incapacitated. In relevant news, North Korea and South Korea exchanged shots at the demilitarized zone although no injuries were reported, and US Secretary of State Pompeo suggested the gunfire exchange was probably accidental. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN (Closed)

Mazda (7261 JT) - Co. April North America sales fell 44.5% Y/Y to 10.9k units. (Newswires)

Nomura Real Estate (3231 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 48.9bln vs. Prev. JPY 45.9bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Resona Holdings (8303 JT) - Co. cuts FY net guidance to 152mln from JPY 60bln due to impact from virus and lower securities gains. (Newswires)

SoftBank (9984 JT) - Co. is said to cut around 10% of its international workforce. (Newswires)

Other News - Japanese PM Abe will consult with experts on Monday regarding extending the national state of emergency declaration to May 31st. (NHK)

subject: US President Trump says he believes there will be a coronavirus vaccine by year-end, adds wants schools and universities to be open in September
US President Trump acknowledges virus could flare up again and said we may have to put out a fire
RBA says excess cash at exchange settlement accounts at AUD 60.6bln vs. Prev.  AUD 63.7bln

US President Trump says during virtual town hall that we can have it both ways with opening the economy and staying safe, sees 75k-100k deaths from coronavirus and again questions China and warnings of the virus
South Korea Core CPI (Apr) Y/Y 0.1% (Prev. 0.4%); lowest reading since November 1999
Nordea says bearish channel in AUD/NZD remains intact and suggest short position is compelling in which they target 1.0200 with a stop loss of 1.0820
ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR IS NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights include: Regional PMIs, Australia Buidling Approvals, holiday closures in China and Japan
US equity futures begin on the back foot after last Friday's losses with Emini S&P gapping lower by 1% to below 2800, while T-notes benefit from the early jitters ahead of this week's risk events
Auckland, New Zealand average house prices rose 3.6% Y/Y and house sales volume fell 17% Y/Y according to Barfoot and Thompson
US CDC reports total coronavirus cases as of previous day at 1600EDT increased to 1,133,486 (Prev. 1,092,815), while total death toll was at 65,735 (Prev. 64,283)
Westpac (WBC AT) H1 net profit attributable fell 62% Y/Y to AUD 1.19bln, cash earnings AUD 993mln vs. Prev. AUD 3.30bln Y/Y, defers decision on dividends
Westpac (WBC AT) H1 net profit attributable fell 62% Y/Y to AUD 1.19bln, cash earnings AUD 993mln vs. Prev. AUD 3.30bln Y/Y, defers decision on dividends
Senior sources in US Republican Senate Conference reportedly want to wait before approving another coronavirus stimulus package
AP reports that a new US intelligence analysis states that China intentionally concealed severity of coronavirus pandemic to stock up on critical medical supplies needed to combat the outbreak
analysis_details: • As a guide, US Secretary of State Pompeo recently stated that there is enormous evidence that the coronavirus outbreak originated in a laboratory in Wuhan, China.

subject: DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

US President Trump said the FDA approved Gilead's (GILD) Remdesivir for emergency use authorization and that the Co. is donating 1mln vials of the drug, while VP Pence said the 1mln vials of remdesivir will start being distributed to hospitals on Monday. (Newswires)

White House Press Secretary said President Trump saw intelligence that suggested COVID-19 had its origins in a Wuhan lab. Furthermore, US Secretary of State Pompeo also stated that there is enormous evidence that the coronavirus outbreak originated in a laboratory in Wuhan, China but didn’t provide evidence to support the claims. While he accused China of stonewalling investigations and refusing to co-operate with experts. (Newswires/BBC)

New Jersey Governor Murphy said he will announce a plan for school reopenings on Monday. Elsewhere, New York City Mayor De Blasio commented that reopening the city is "obviously a few months away at the minimum", while the Washington State Governor extended the stay at home order to May 31st. (Newswires)

UK is looking to relax the lockdown measures beginning May 26th according to The Sun, while it was also reported that PM Johnson’s plan to relax the lockdown in approaching weeks include workplace proposals such as staggered shifts, curtailing hot desking and face-to-face meetings, while staff canteens will remain shut and lifts kept half empty. (The Sun/FT)

UK Cabinet Minister Gove commented that a staged easing of the lockdown would mean restrictions could be imposed to tackle localized outbreaks and also stated that the UK will be piloting a new test, as well as trace and track procedures in the Isle of Wight. (Newswires)

UK coronavirus death toll rose by 315 to 28, 446 vs. Prev. increase of 621 deaths, while France’s death toll rose by 135 to 24,895 vs. Prev. increase of 166 deaths and Italy’s death toll rose by 174 to 28,884 vs. Prev. increase of 474 to represent its lowest daily death toll since the lockdown began on March 10th. (Newswires)

India extended its nationwide lockdown from May 4th for two weeks but will permit "considerable relaxations" in districts marked as Green and Orange Zones. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

Japanese PM Abe will consult with experts on Monday regarding extending the national state of emergency declaration to May 31st. (NHK)

Indian government is to reportedly cap overall spending on its virus package at around USD 60bln due to credit rating concerns and the government will likely give tax holidays to some businesses and individuals in its next package, according to sources. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK is to start trade talks with the US in the upcoming week. (Newswires)

BoE is to release its May 7th Monetary Policy decision at 0700BST. (Newswires)

Ireland’s Green Party said to enter formal talks with Fianna Fail and Fine Gael with a view to forming a government, while it added any government programme must be transformative on climate action or they will withdraw from discussions. (Newswires)

ECB said Eurozone GDP may fail to return to 2019 levels until 2022 and confirmed it forecasts a sharp contraction in GDP this year before a 6% increase in 2021 in a mild scenario. (Newswires)

UK Markit/CIPS Manufacturing PMI Final (Apr) 32.6 vs. Exp. 32.8 (Prev. 32.9) 

 

FX

Canada’s Finance Minister announced that BoC's new Governor will be Tiff Macklem. There were also comments from incoming BoC Governor Macklem that a seamless transition will be his first priority, while he added that there are disruptive effects from negative interest rates and he is comfortable with lower bound at 0.25%. Furthermore, he noted that there will not be a snap back to normal from the crisis. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

Baker Hughes US rig count (w/e May 1st); Oil -53 at 325, Nat Gas -4 at 81, Total -57 at 408. (Newswires)

OPEC+ alliance is aiming to ensure a compliance rate of over 100% with its latest output cut agreement, according to OPEC President (Algerian Energy Minister) cited by Argus Media. (Twitter)

White House Press Secretary stated the US is filling the SPR with 75mln bbls of oil and that the US wants to negotiate the next stimulus bill immediately. (Newswires) 

Texas Railroad Commission Chairman Christian said the state will not be reducing output in which he stated that he and Commissioner Craddick oppose proration, while he thinks the issue is settled and is disturbed seeing it viewed as a big question heading into the commission meeting this week. (Energy Intel)

 

GEOPOLITICS

North Korean leader Kim visited a factory in his first public appearance in 20 days and which follows conflicting reports in which some suggested he may have died or was incapacitated. In relevant news, North Korea and South Korea exchanged shots at the demilitarized zone although no injuries were reported, and US Secretary of State Pompeo suggested the gunfire exchange was probably accidental. (Newswires)

 

US

Fed's Kaplan (voter, dove) said the US is likely to see a 20% jobless rate but sees it ending the year at between 8%-10% and suggested that US GDP might contract 30% in Q2 but is likely to end the year between 4.5%-5.0%. Kaplan also reiterated that rates will remain low for long and that the Fed will need to do more in this period. (Newswires)

Fed's Barkin (non-voter, hawk) said the downturn is likely to last more than a couple of months and the US needs to lay the plans for what further help might be needed. Barkin also stated that it is possible to return to "normal operations" of the economy but at a gradual pace and assuming health protocols like masks and temperature taking are in place, while he expects a "meaningful" pickup in Q3 and the trajectory from there depends on consumer confidence and health outcomes. (Newswires)

Fed's Bullard (non-voter, dove) sees an eventual need for a "far more granular, far more risk-based" approach to reopening the economy and suggested if the crisis extends for too long there is a risk that the economy won't recover swiftly. Bullard added the Fed has made commitments to remain at low rates until the economy gets on a better footing, while he added that as long as the shock is temporary, the economy could recover in H2 this year and he thinks inflation could be maintained not too far from the 2% target. (WSJ)

NEC Director Kudlow said he sees very strong growth in H2 2020 and that US is in "pause mode" for 20-30 days to observe the latest tranche of stimulus, while he added that the White House emphasis will be on future growth incentives and reiterated that US debt is 'sacrosanct' When asked again on whether the US may cancel holdings of US Treasury debt held by China. (Newswires)

NYSE is to hold a meeting with the floor community on Tuesday and officials may address a timetable for reopening, while they are said to be unlikely to set a firm date but could provide guidance, according to FBN's Gasparino. (Fox)

  • US Markit Manufacturing PMI Final (Apr) 36.1 (Prev. 36.9). (Newswires)
  • US ISM Manufacturing PMI (Apr) 41.5 vs. Exp. 36.9 (Prev. 49.1)
  • US ISM Manufacturing Employment Index (Apr) 27.5 vs. Exp. 37.0 (Prev. 43.8)
  • US Construction Spending (Mar) M/M 0.9% vs. Exp. -3.5% (Prev. -1.3%, Rev. -2.5%)

 

MARKET RECAP

The week ended on a subdued note, with much of Europe away on a market holiday. The tone, however, was of caution in thin trading conditions, amid punchy rhetoric from US President Trump regarding China on late Thursday, as well as underwhelming earnings from AMZN and AAPL, which were in contrast to GOOG, FB, MSFT results earlier in the week. Tesla (TSLA) announced it has reduced the cost of its China-made Model 3 by 10% to qualify for subsidies. During hours CEO Musk Tweeted in his opinion that the stock is currently too high, although it was initially unclear whether or not he was hacked as the post was followed with a string of peculiar tweets afterwards. WSJ later reported it was not a joke. Boeing Company (BA) announced it had completed a successful first flight of its second 777x jet. Walmart (WMT) confirmed it is planning to launch a 2-hour grocery delivery service names “Express”. Wells Fargo (WFC) is reportedly no longer accept applications for home equity lines of credit as of April 30th, 2020. Zoom Video (ZM) CEO is reportedly subject of a probe from the Education Department where it is investigating the University of Texas for possibly fault financial disclosures and is seeking any dealings with Huawei, Zoom CEO and the Chinese lab being probed as a potential virus source, according to WSJ citing sources. SPX -2.75% at 2832, NDQ -3.14% at 8718, DJIA -2.55% at 23,724.

The TPLEX lacked direction on Friday amid light news flow and month-end passing. Rates had been heading lower overnight, with one desk noting passive month-end index-linked purchasing. However, as the US session got underway the gains were gradually reversed, despite wider risk off amid a cocktail of anti-China rhetoric and disappointing AMZN/AAPL earnings. A slightly better than expected headline ISM manufacturing managed provide some support to the risk tone, nudging T-Notes lower somewhat, although moves were very contained. On the supply front, corporate issuance cooled to end the week following the Boeing jumbo USD 25bln deal on Thursday, although investors may be cautious about bidding rates lower ahead of next week’s Treasury refunding announcement (May 6th), where the Treasury will explain how it plans to funds its ballooning deficit (it will likely launch the much touted 20-year Bond); furthermore, with corporates emerging from the other side of earnings, companies will be likely to flood the pipeline with debt offerings as many look to pay off short term credit facilities that have been maxed out amid the economy standstill. Elsewhere, the NY Fed announced it would be tapering its Treasury purchases to USD 8bln per day for next week from this week’s USD 10bln – note that the pace of the tapering has been declining in recent weeks, where last week it cut to USD 10bln from USD 15bln per day. By settlement, yields were little changed, 2s +1bps at 0.20%, 10s +1bps at 0.63%, and 30s unchanged at 1.27%. US T-note futures (M0) settled 6 ticks lower at 138-28.
